Description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency reached a Clean Air Act settlement with Lucite International, Inc. requiring the chemical manufacturer to install pollution controls costing an estimated $16 million on three emission sources at its Memphis, Tennessee plant in addition to paying a civil penalty of $1.8 million and performing a supplemental environmental project worth $1.3 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/October/05_enrd_546.html

Description: Nine Japan-based companies and two executives agreed to plead guilty and to pay a total of more than $740 million in criminal fines for their roles in separate conspiracies to fix the prices of more than 30 different products sold to U.S. car manufacturers and installed in cars sold in the United States and elsewhere.

Description: Union Bank of California, N.A. entered into a deferred prosecution agreement on charges of failing to maintain an effective anti-money laundering program and agreed to forfeit $21.6 million to the U.S. government.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2007/September/07_crm_726.html

Description: The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency announced the assessment of concurrent civil money penalties, each $10 million, against Union Bank of California, N.A. of San Francisco, California, for violations of the Bank Secrecy Act. Union Bank, without admitting or denying the allegations, consented to payment of the civil money penalties, which were to be satisfied by a single payment of $10 million to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. Union Bank also consented to issuance of a Cease and Desist Order by the OCC.
Agency: Treasury Department Financial Crimes Enforcement Network
Info Source: https://www.fincen.gov/news/news-releases/fincen-and-occ-assess-civil-money-penalties-against-union-bank-california

Description: A group of 11 companies agreed to pay a total of $25.03 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they conspired to fix the prices of vitamins added to foods such as ready-to-eat cereals. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: http://www.illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2009_12/20091202.html

Description: Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi-UFJ agreed to pay $250 million to the Department of Financial Services for violations of New York Banking Law in connection with transactions involving countries and entities subject to international sanctions, including the regimes of Iran, Sudan, and Myanmar.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Info Source: https://www.dfs.ny.gov/reports_and_publications/press_releases/pr1306201

Description: Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) was penalized an additional $315 million -- on top of a $250 million penalty in 2013 -- for misleading regulators regarding its transactions with Iran, Sudan, Myanmar, and other sanctioned entities.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Info Source: https://www.dfs.ny.gov/reports_and_publications/press_releases/pr1411181

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into an agreement with MUFG Bank, formerly The Bank of Toyko-Mitsubishi UFJ Lt., under which MUFG agreed to pay $33 million to settle claims related to the conversion of state-licensed branches in New York, Illinois, and California and its state-licensed agency offices in Texas to federally licensed branches and agency offices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
Info Source: https://www.dfs.ny.gov/reports_and_publications/press_releases/pr1906241
